Coach Hambleton Responsponsible For Barring
Negro Harrier
A small informal inquiry and discussion of the circumstances surrounding the exclusion of Johnson
Williams, cross-country runner
from Schenectady, N. Y., by the
Johns Hopkins chapter of Spiked
Shoe, was sponsored by the Liberal
Club Wednesday.
The chief fact disclosed was that
the entire responsibility seems to
rest upon Coach Waldo Hambleton,
of Johns Hopkins, who suggested
the visitor be barred because he
feared difficulties might be raised
by local high schools in which he
holds a teaching position.

Maryland Casualty Auditorium Selected As Site
For Show

Deploring the present condition of
athletics on the campus, Omicron
Delta Kappa, campus honorary fraternity, sought a statement from
President Joseph S. Ames, in a recent letter asking "a decisive move
in the matter."
Stating that the present situation
is the source of much comment
among the students, the letter,
signed by Donaldson Kelly, president of the fraternity, pointed to an
editorial appearing in the December
12th issue Of THE NEWS-LETTER as
offering "evidence of the feeling
among Hopkins men."

Closing two months of prolonged
work, with a final dress rehearsal
last night, the Barnstormers will
present "The Front Page", a newspaper drama by Ben Hecht and
Charles McArthur, tomorrow night
at 8:30 p. m., at the Maryland Casualty Auditorium. The performance will be followed by a dance at
which Miss Jeannette Bittner will
be the guest of honor and which
features The Townsmen. The orchestra will also play in the pit during the intermissions.

Organization Opposed

Felix Bendann, president of
Spiked Shoe, stated that his organization was unanimously against the
restriction but sanctioned it because
of Mr. Hambleton.

erly accredited part of the undergraduate department
at Homewood.
It seems almost unbelievable that such a constellation of luminaries should be either so unconcerned
and supercilious or else otherwise occupied that the
undergraduate is denied the privilege of culling at
least a general idea of the thoughts and analytical
methods which have made them famous. We're not
hollering for our money's worth or anything else so
banal, nor do we want to become millstones about the
intellectual necks of the faculty, but it impresses us
as a direct subversion of educational method to disallow our right to hear these men. The Hopkins was
founded upon the idea that the students and faculty
are partners in searching after knowledge, but it is a
misinterpretation of that doctrine to require that a
student be almost a genius before he can have the
benefit of the surveillance of the masters.
President Ames has, within recent times, urged
that the research work be turned over more and more
to the younger men on the faculty and that the older
and more experienced men take the burden of teaching. His recommendations are not being fulfilled.
The active minds of the vigorous and youthful men
of vision are bogged down with the duties of pedagogy, while the men who are ideally suited for this
instruction because of their experience are allowed
to go to seed without impressing their personalities
and attainments on budding students.
Teaching elementary knowledge is not cheapening. Quite the contrary, it is an occupation dignified
by eminent example in previous generations and is,
if anything, ennobling.

Score One For 0. D. K.
It warmed the cockles of our hearts, it did.
0. D. K., in the manner of the best traditions and
in a commendable spirit, took up our torch for the
crusade of the century: The Rescue of The Oppressed Athlete. A noble gesture, gentlemen!
The honor society rang the bell on two points.
First, it seized time by the forelock and plunged
into a useful project as a result of its first meeting with the new initiates. Second, it has taken
up its task with intelligence by approaching the
administration respectfully and yet assuredly.
The tone of the letter printed in our news columns today shows sincerity and hits right at the
crux of the question, namely, the seemingly detached attitude of the administration toward the
athletic problem. All the charges, insinuations,
and direct aspersions which we have made have
not been sufficient to make anyone take the responsibility of answering our perfectly reasonable
queries.
President Ames has said repeatedly that he
entertains a high respect for the opinions of Omicron Delta Kappa because of its standards of integrity. 'We shall be interested in his answer to
its letter. A clear-cut description of the administration's policy would considerably clarify the
atmopshere.

Kamerad!
After repeated jogging by correspondents in our
letter collmns we promise to sponsor a poll on the
question of compulsory fees. We have hesitated to
precipitate any general opinion upon the question
because of the desperate financial difficulty of the
University. For instance, if there had been no compulsory activity fee this year there could have been
no activities at all because, primarily, of the fourthousand dollar debt incurred when the banks tied
up our funds of last year, and the consequent claim
upon this year's operating funds.
In the case of the athletic fee, however, we are
not so sympathetic, as a few of our readers may,
doubtless, have gleaned from previous remarks herein.
So we yield to the pressure and will attempt to ascertain student opinion shortly after the Christmas
holiday.

Our Sympathies
We are sorry to hear of the recent death of the
father of Dr. William S. Holt, associate in American
History. We extend our sincere sympathies and
regrets to Dr. Holt in his bereavement.

Cam bus Brevities

Our Distinguished Faculty
Generally speaking, the Johns Hopkins can be
credited with one of the outstanding collegiate faculties of the world. Men of international reputation
and high accomplishment, recognized as authorities
in their respective fields, certainly are anything but
scarce in the University roster. Yet to the large
majority of undergraduates these personalities are as
inaccessible and almost unknown as if they were not
in the professorial array at all.
It must be conceded that when a man has attained distinction that he becomes obligated immediately in a great many ways. Lectures, articles, dinners, social functions, to say nothing at all of his own
research work, monopolize his every waking hour.
His duties are gruelling and exacting. But he should
donate to the University in return for high salary
considerably more than his reputation; there is a
modicum of service due as well.
Descending from the general to the specific, we
are anxious to point out to the readers of THE NEWSLETTER the results of a compilation of data recently
made in our office. It is information available for any
one having the perverseness of industry to dig it up:
we selected at random from the Faculty of Philosophy the names of twenty-three men who are representative of this distinguished group of academic authorities of which we are justly proud. It may be
safely said that this sample group draws down an
average salary of well over $10,000 annually per
man, if we may rely on obscure sources of information and deduction. Of the twenty-three only two
give listed undergraduate courses; three others hold
classes in the Teachers' College, which is not a prop-

kidding Bill Hansch and Jim Plemmons about
their race for the favor of Little Miss Fisher (Al's

Dame lass for quite a while, but now it appears

By Millard Langfeld, Jr.

AS THE shouting and the tumult dies, it becomes increasingly more apparent that the Volstead
issue is anything but dead. Nor should such a realization bring any great measure of surprise. It
is, indeed, naive to expect that the accumulated customs and practices of fourteen years could be swept
away by one stroke of an official pen. It simply isn't
human nature.
AND YET there was a not inconsiderable group
of just such naive optimists. Repeal to them presented the perfect panacea for all the ills of a suffering nation. From kidnaping to the complexities
of the gold standard, there was no problem that was
not sure to be lost to sight forever beneath the contents of the flowing bowl.

NOR IS the existence of such a state of affairs
entirely without its logic. Ultra high taxation rates
still keep a legal drink out of the mouths of the vast
middle class who labored long to bring legality about.
The results of this situation are as wrong as they are
obvious.

BUT IT is not the time to make excuses nor
to convert the obvious into smart alibis. As the
Scripps-Howard newspapers have so fittingly proclaimed, it is smart legality that is now the vital thing.
The bootleg rum traffic, with all its attendant evils of
racketeering and of general crime, is a product of the
public. This Frankenstein is a creation of the people,
and it is only through their power that it can meet
destruction.
THE question before the country today is whether
ALL THIS was fine and good—in theory. But America as a nation is really wed to law. High revetheories aren't facts, and now the passage of the nue regulations can and will be altered. But the temtwenty-first amendment has brought its own problem perament of a people is above the statute books.

PrHOUSANDS of men are still trying to borrow a copy of the last
issue of ESQUIRE—the magazine for men only. Those who were
fortunate enough to buy one, did so the morning it came out. By
noon most of the men's stores and newsstands were frantically reordering and, though we printed over forty thousand additional
copies, that wasn't enough.
Anyway, the second issue of the first and only general magazine
for men is out today. And if you were one of those who got left
at the post in the scramble for copies of the first issue (or even if
you weren't) this is to offer fair warning that the first issue of
ESQUIRE gave only a sort of budding notion of what this second
issue is like.
Ernest Hemingway, John Dos Passos, Gilbert Seldes, Morley
Callaghan, Montague Glass, George Ade, Robert Buckner, Bobby
Jones—all back!
But, in addition,(slow down, big names ahead) we've included
Emil Ludwig, Paul Morand, Louis Golding, Westbrook Pegler,
Irvin S. Cobb, Dwight Fiske, Alexandre Millerand, Andre Maurois,
Owen Johnson, Thomas Burke,Jack Dempsey, Louis Joseph Vance,
and—well, this could go on forever—or at least for 160 large and
lively pages of the most varied entertainment a man ever picked
up between two covers—and couldn't lay down.
There is actually the wordage-total of two popular novels in
this one issue. There are over forty pages in color. There are full
page cartoons galore. There are full-color pages of men's clothes
that are men's clothes—not "fashions." (We mean, you can
wear them.)
As for the ladies, we have just one word of comfort. ESQUIRE
makes a swell Christmas gift for any man. With this issue it

NIEBUHR ANALYZES
DYING LIBERALISM
Believes Universities To Be
Its Last Bulwark; Lists
Opponents
Stating that the universities sometimes seem to be its last bulwark,
Reinhold Niebuhr, Supper Club
speaker Tuesday, gave an analysis
of the dying culture of liberalism.
Optimism, a tenacious adherence
to liberty and rationalism, he said,
were its components. Optimism
consists of a belief in evolution or
the uncritical transfer of biological
facts to history, a belief in the natural goodness of human nature as
well as in the harmlessness of human egoism (Adam Smith), and a
belief in the progress especially of
science which implied that man
could live in complete emancipation
if he conquered nature.

Williams, cross-country runner

Club Wednesday.

erly accredited part of the undergraduate department
at Homewood.
It seems almost unbelievable that such a constellation of luminaries should be either so unconcerned
and supercilious or else otherwise occupied that the
undergraduate is denied the privilege of culling at
least a general idea of the thoughts and analytical
methods which have made them famous. We're not
hollering for our money's worth or anything else so
banal, nor do we want to become millstones about the
intellectual necks of the faculty, but it impresses us
as a direct subversion of educational method to disallow our right to hear these men. The Hopkins was
founded upon the idea that the students and faculty
are partners in searching after knowledge, but it is a
misinterpretation of that doctrine to require that a
student be almost a genius before he can have the
benefit of the surveillance of the masters.
President Ames has, within recent times, urged
that the research work be turned over more and more
to the younger men on the faculty and that the older
and more experienced men take the burden of teaching. His recommendations are not being fulfilled.
The active minds of the vigorous and youthful men
of vision are bogged down with the duties of pedagogy, while the men who are ideally suited for this
instruction because of their experience are allowed
to go to seed without impressing their personalities
and attainments on budding students.
Teaching elementary knowledge is not cheapening. Quite the contrary, it is an occupation dignified
by eminent example in previous generations and is,
if anything, ennobling.

Score One For 0. D. K.
It warmed the cockles of our hearts, it did.
0. D. K., in the manner of the best traditions and
in a commendable spirit, took up our torch for the
crusade of the century: The Rescue of The Oppressed Athlete. A noble gesture, gentlemen!
The honor society rang the bell on two points.
First, it seized time by the forelock and plunged
into a useful project as a result of its first meeting with the new initiates. Second, it has taken
up its task with intelligence by approaching the
administration respectfully and yet assuredly.
The tone of the letter printed in our news columns today shows sincerity and hits right at the
crux of the question, namely, the seemingly detached attitude of the administration toward the
athletic problem. All the charges, insinuations,
and direct aspersions which we have made have
not been sufficient to make anyone take the responsibility of answering our perfectly reasonable
queries.
President Ames has said repeatedly that he
entertains a high respect for the opinions of Omicron Delta Kappa because of its standards of integrity. 'We shall be interested in his answer to
its letter. A clear-cut description of the administration's policy would considerably clarify the
atmopshere.

Kamerad!
After repeated jogging by correspondents in our
letter collmns we promise to sponsor a poll on the
question of compulsory fees. We have hesitated to
precipitate any general opinion upon the question
because of the desperate financial difficulty of the
University. For instance, if there had been no compulsory activity fee this year there could have been
no activities at all because, primarily, of the fourthousand dollar debt incurred when the banks tied
up our funds of last year, and the consequent claim
upon this year's operating funds.
In the case of the athletic fee, however, we are
not so sympathetic, as a few of our readers may,
doubtless, have gleaned from previous remarks herein.
So we yield to the pressure and will attempt to ascertain student opinion shortly after the Christmas
holiday.

Our Sympathies
We are sorry to hear of the recent death of the
father of Dr. William S. Holt, associate in American
History. We extend our sincere sympathies and
regrets to Dr. Holt in his bereavement.

Cam bus Brevities

Our Distinguished Faculty
Generally speaking, the Johns Hopkins can be
credited with one of the outstanding collegiate faculties of the world. Men of international reputation
and high accomplishment, recognized as authorities
in their respective fields, certainly are anything but
scarce in the University roster. Yet to the large
majority of undergraduates these personalities are as
inaccessible and almost unknown as if they were not
in the professorial array at all.
It must be conceded that when a man has attained distinction that he becomes obligated immediately in a great many ways. Lectures, articles, dinners, social functions, to say nothing at all of his own
research work, monopolize his every waking hour.
His duties are gruelling and exacting. But he should
donate to the University in return for high salary
considerably more than his reputation; there is a
modicum of service due as well.
Descending from the general to the specific, we
are anxious to point out to the readers of THE NEWSLETTER the results of a compilation of data recently
made in our office. It is information available for any
one having the perverseness of industry to dig it up:
we selected at random from the Faculty of Philosophy the names of twenty-three men who are representative of this distinguished group of academic authorities of which we are justly proud. It may be
safely said that this sample group draws down an
average salary of well over $10,000 annually per
man, if we may rely on obscure sources of information and deduction. Of the twenty-three only two
give listed undergraduate courses; three others hold
classes in the Teachers' College, which is not a prop-

By Millard Langfeld, Jr.

AS THE shouting and the tumult dies, it becomes increasingly more apparent that the Volstead
issue is anything but dead. Nor should such a realization bring any great measure of surprise. It
is, indeed, naive to expect that the accumulated customs and practices of fourteen years could be swept
away by one stroke of an official pen. It simply isn't
human nature.
AND YET there was a not inconsiderable group
of just such naive optimists. Repeal to them presented the perfect panacea for all the ills of a suffering nation. From kidnaping to the complexities
of the gold standard, there was no problem that was
not sure to be lost to sight forever beneath the contents of the flowing bowl.

NOR IS the existence of such a state of affairs
entirely without its logic. Ultra high taxation rates
still keep a legal drink out of the mouths of the vast
middle class who labored long to bring legality about.
The results of this situation are as wrong as they are
obvious.

BUT IT is not the time to make excuses nor
to convert the obvious into smart alibis. As the
Scripps-Howard newspapers have so fittingly proclaimed, it is smart legality that is now the vital thing.
The bootleg rum traffic, with all its attendant evils of
racketeering and of general crime, is a product of the
public. This Frankenstein is a creation of the people,
and it is only through their power that it can meet
destruction.
THE question before the country today is whether

PrHOUSANDS of men are still trying to borrow a copy of the last
issue of ESQUIRE—the magazine for men only. Those who were
fortunate enough to buy one, did so the morning it came out. By
noon most of the men's stores and newsstands were frantically reordering and, though we printed over forty thousand additional
copies, that wasn't enough.
Anyway, the second issue of the first and only general magazine
for men is out today. And if you were one of those who got left
at the post in the scramble for copies of the first issue (or even if
you weren't) this is to offer fair warning that the first issue of
ESQUIRE gave only a sort of budding notion of what this second
issue is like.
Ernest Hemingway, John Dos Passos, Gilbert Seldes, Morley
Callaghan, Montague Glass, George Ade, Robert Buckner, Bobby
Jones—all back!
But, in addition,(slow down, big names ahead) we've included
Emil Ludwig, Paul Morand, Louis Golding, Westbrook Pegler,
Irvin S. Cobb, Dwight Fiske, Alexandre Millerand, Andre Maurois,
Owen Johnson, Thomas Burke,Jack Dempsey, Louis Joseph Vance,
and—well, this could go on forever—or at least for 160 large and
lively pages of the most varied entertainment a man ever picked
up between two covers—and couldn't lay down.
There is actually the wordage-total of two popular novels in
this one issue. There are over forty pages in color. There are full
page cartoons galore. There are full-color pages of men's clothes
that are men's clothes—not "fashions." (We mean, you can
wear them.)
As for the ladies, we have just one word of comfort. ESQUIRE
makes a swell Christmas gift for any man. With this issue it
becomesa monthly-50cents a copy,5 dollarsfor a year'ssubscription.

NIEBUHR ANALYZES
DYING LIBERALISM
Believes Universities To Be
Its Last Bulwark; Lists
Opponents
Stating that the universities sometimes seem to be its last bulwark,
Reinhold Niebuhr, Supper Club
speaker Tuesday, gave an analysis
of the dying culture of liberalism.
Optimism, a tenacious adherence
to liberty and rationalism, he said,
were its components. Optimism
consists of a belief in evolution or
the uncritical transfer of biological
facts to history, a belief in the natural goodness of human nature as
well as in the harmlessness of human egoism (Adam Smith), and a
belief in the progress especially of
science which implied that man
could live in complete emancipation
if he conquered nature.
